item.title: Alien abduction entities
item.description:
Alien Abduction Entities 🔗

This Wikipedia entry focuses on the beings alleged to be responsible for alien abductions, particularly those involving forced medical examinations with an emphasis on the reproductive system. It highlights the skepticism surrounding the phenomenon within the scientific and mental health communities, attributing such experiences to psychological and environmental factors rather than literal events.

Alleged Motivations 🔗

This section explores the purported reasons behind alien abductions, as claimed by experiencers. Dr. John G. Miller’s research indicates that abductees often report entities claiming a “right” to perform invasive procedures. UFOlogist Jenny Randles’ study of 50 abduction claims reveals that in approximately 60% of cases, abductors provided insights into their motivations, often involving long-term surveillance and interaction. These motivations form a narrative centered on the entities targeting individuals with unique qualities for repeated abductions, during which information is subconsciously implanted for later activation, potentially coinciding with major Earth changes. Different entity types, such as “Nordics” and “Grays,” are said to have varying motivations, with Nordics being perceived as more benevolent.

Types 🔗

This section categorizes the different types of entities reported in alien abduction claims. It presents two tables summarizing these types based on different studies. The first table, based on a survey of 203 pre-1985 abduction claims, lists entities such as Short Humanoids (including short grey aliens), Average Height Humanoids (including tall grey aliens), Tall Humanoids, Mummy-like beings, Miscellaneous Humanoids (including reptoids and hairy dwarves), Human-like beings (including Nordics), and Non-human entities. The second table, based on Claudier Covo’s Brazilian Alien Typology from a study of 138 alleged abductions, categorizes entities as Alpha (0.8–1.4 m tall), Beta (1.4–2 m tall), Gamma (over 2 m tall), Delta (animals, robots, etc.), Omega (energy beings), and Sigma (very short beings about 0.15 m tall). The section also mentions “Mantid aliens” as frequently reported by abductees, often described as being in charge of the grays.

Reported Technology 🔗

This section details the technological capabilities allegedly displayed by alien abduction entities. Claimants report being levitated, flown around, and witnessing entities passing through walls. Further claimed technical capabilities have been described – including in various books by ufologists – generally without any detailed hypotheses regarding how such appearances or actual capabilities may or may not be possible.

Weapon 🔗

This subsection focuses on a specific weapon allegedly used by grey aliens, as described in Nick Pope’s book The Uninvited. The device is described as a black, cylindrical object, similar in size to a pencil, with a bluish light on one end. It is reportedly used to subdue combative abductees by numbing their will, resembling a Star Trek “phaser” firing a bluish-white beam.

Medical 🔗

This subsection describes a medical device reported by Linda Moulton Howe, based on independent reports from at least two alleged abductions. The device is a pencil-sized cylinder with a light on one end, used in a manner analogous to a surgical scalpel. One abductee described the device opening the chest bloodlessly in “slow motion,” comparing it to a flower blossoming in time-lapse photography, and described the device as “opening the body with sound.”

Plausibility and Veracity 🔗

This section addresses the plausibility and veracity of alien abduction claims, particularly focusing on the influence of hypnosis, geography, culture, and science fiction on abductor descriptions.

Hypnosis as an Influence on Abductor Descriptions 🔗

This subsection examines the impact of hypnosis on the descriptions of abducting beings. Folklorist Thomas E. Bullard notes that the absence of monstrous types in reliable cases contradicts the idea that Hollywood influences abduction reports. He also observes that hypnotically assisted recall tends to produce descriptions of “standard” Grey humanoids, while cases without hypnosis include more variety. Bullard raises the question of whether hypnosis shapes memories or reveals the true appearance of the beings.

Geography and Culture as Influences on Abductor Descriptions 🔗

This subsection explores how geographic and cultural factors influence the details of abduction reports. Robert Sheaffer observes that in North America, large-headed gray aliens are predominant, while in Britain, abduction aliens are usually tall, blond, and Nordic, and South America tends toward more bizarre creatures. The section also notes that common elements in abduction descriptions vary by region and local culture, with only a few elements being consistent worldwide, such as otherworldly sensations, mind control, repressed memories, and sexual experiences, which are also common in stories of encounters with faeries, demons, and other magical creatures. In Brazil, there are strong links between the abduction phenomenon and spiritist traditions, with claims of medical practitioners operating out of a space laboratory.

Science Fiction as an Influence 🔗

This subsection discusses the potential influence of science fiction on abduction reports. Sheaffer notes similarities between aliens depicted in early science fiction films, such as Invaders From Mars, and those reported to have abducted people. Commonalities exist in the appearances, behavior, technology, and societies of fictional and allegedly real abductors. The “abduction narrative” was already established in fictional form by 1930 in a Buck Rogers comic strip. However, Bullard does not see evidence for influence on abduction claimants from science fiction sources.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction_entities

item.title: Area 51
item.description:
Area 51 🔗

Area 51, officially called Homey Airport (KXTA) or Groom Lake, is a highly classified United States Air Force (USAF) facility located within the Nevada Test and Training Range. It’s a remote detachment administered by Edwards Air Force Base. While details of its operations are not public, it’s widely believed to support the development and testing of experimental aircraft and weapons systems. The intense secrecy surrounding the base has made it a central subject of conspiracy theories and UFO folklore. The CIA publicly acknowledged the base’s existence in 2013, following a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request.

Geography 🔗

Area 51 🔗

The original rectangular base is part of the “Groom box,” a restricted airspace area. It’s connected to the Nevada Test Site (NTS) road network, with roads leading to Mercury and Yucca Flat. Groom Lake Road runs northeast through the Jumbled Hills, past a security checkpoint, and eventually connects with State Route 375, the “Extraterrestrial Highway,” south of Rachel, Nevada. Area 51 shares a border with the Yucca Flat region of the Nevada Test Site, the location of many nuclear tests. The Yucca Mountain nuclear waste repository is southwest of Groom Lake.

Groom Lake 🔗

Groom Lake is a salt flat in Nevada used for runways of the Nellis Bombing Range Test Site airport (XTA/KXTA) on the north of the Area 51 USAF military installation. It’s located within the Groom Lake Valley portion of the Tonopah Basin, south of Rachel, Nevada.

History 🔗

The origin of the name “Area 51” is unclear. The facility has also been referred to as “Dreamland” and “Paradise Ranch.” The special use airspace around the field is referred to as Restricted Area 4808 North (R-4808N). Lead and silver were discovered in the Groom Range in 1864, and mining continued until the early 1950s. The airfield on the Groom Lake site began service in 1942 as Indian Springs Air Force Auxiliary Field.

U-2 program 🔗

The CIA established the Groom Lake test facility in April 1955 for Project AQUATONE: the development of the Lockheed U-2 strategic reconnaissance aircraft. Project director Richard M. Bissell Jr. chose Groom Lake as the testing site due to its secrecy and ideal location. Lockheed’s Kelly Johnson named the area “Paradise Ranch” to encourage workers to move there. The Ranch initially consisted of shelters, workshops, and trailer homes. The base received its first U-2 delivery on 24 July 1955.

OXCART program 🔗

Project OXCART was established in August 1959 for work on the Lockheed A-12. Construction of A-12 test facilities began in September 1960, including a new runway. Reynolds Electrical and Engineering Company (REECo) upgraded base facilities and built a new runway diagonally across the lakebed. The CIA facility received eight USAF F-101 Voodoos for training, two T-33 Shooting Star trainers, a C-130 Hercules for cargo transport, a U-3A, a helicopter, and a Cessna 180. Lockheed provided an F-104 Starfighter. The first A-12 test aircraft arrived at Groom Lake on 28 February 1962 and made its first flight 26 April 1962. Groom was also the site of the first Lockheed D-21 drone test flight on 22 December 1964. By the end of 1963, nine A-12s were at Area 51, assigned to the CIA-operated “1129th Special Activities Squadron”.

D-21 Tagboard 🔗

Following the loss of Gary Powers’ U-2 over the Soviet Union, there were discussions about using the A-12 OXCART as an unpiloted drone aircraft. The project was designated “Q-12”, later renamed the “D-21”. The first D-21 launch was made on 5 March 1966 with a successful flight. An accident on 30 July 1966 with a fully fueled D-21 caused it to collide with the M-21 launch aircraft. Kelly Johnson cancelled the program. Several more tests were made, none of which met with success. On 15 July 1971, Kelly Johnson received a wire canceling the D-21B program.

Foreign technology evaluation 🔗

During the Cold War, Area 51 played host to an assortment of Soviet-built aircraft. Munir Redfa’s defection with a Mikoyan-Gurevich MiG-21 led to the HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE DRILL and HAVE FERRY programs. The first MiGs flown in the United States were used to evaluate the aircraft in performance, technical, and operational capabilities, pitting the types against U.S. fighters. In August 1966, Iraqi Air Force fighter pilot Captain Munir Redfa defected, flying his MiG-21 to Israel. His aircraft was transferred to Groom Lake in late 1967 for study. In 1968, the US Air Force and Navy jointly formed a project known as HAVE DOUGHNUT. On 12 August 1968, two Syrian air force lieutenants, Walid Adham and Radfan Rifai, took off in a pair of MiG-17Fs on a training mission and landed at the Betzet Landing Field in northern Israel. Prior to the end of 1968 these MiG-17s were transferred from Israeli stocks and added to the Area 51 test fleet. In May 1973, Project HAVE IDEA was formed, which took over from the older HAVE DOUGHNUT, HAVE FERRY and HAVE DRILL projects, and the project was transferred to the Tonopah Test Range Airport. Area 51 also hosted another foreign materiel evaluation program called HAVE GLIB. In 1979, the CIA transferred jurisdiction of the Area 51 site to the Air Force Flight Test Center at Edwards AFB, California. In 2017, a USAF aircraft crashed at the site, killing the pilot, Lt. Colonel Eric “Doc” Schultz.

Have Blue/F-117 program 🔗

The Lockheed Have Blue prototype stealth fighter first flew at Groom in December 1977. On 17 January 1981 the Lockheed test team at Area 51 accepted delivery of the first full-scale development (FSD) prototype, designated YF-117A. On 18 June 1981 Lockheed Skunk Works test pilot Hal Farley lifted the nose of YF-117A off the runway of Area 51. Tactical Air Command (TAC) decided to set up a group-level organization to guide the F-117A to an initial operating capability. That organization became the 4450th Tactical Group, which officially activated on 15 October 1979 at Nellis AFB, Nevada, although the group was physically located at Area 51. On 15 October 1982, Major Alton C. Whitley Jr. became the first USAF 4450th TG pilot to fly the F-117A. Tonopah Test Range Airport was selected for operations of the first USAF F-117 unit, the 4450th Tactical Group (TG). By early 1982, four more YF-117As were operating at the base. Testing of a series of ultra-secret prototypes continued at Area 51 until mid-1981 when testing transitioned to the initial production of F-117 stealth fighters. The F-117s were moved to and from Area 51 by C-5 during darkness to maintain security. While the “Baja Scorpions” were working on the F-117, there was also another group at work in secrecy, known as “the Whalers” working on Tacit Blue. On 17 May 1982, the move of the 4450th TG from Groom Lake to Tonopah was initiated, with the final components of the move completed in early 1983. The R-Unit was inactivated on 30 May 1989. In 1990, the last F-117A was delivered from Lockheed. In February/March 1992 the test unit moved from Area 51 to the USAF Palmdale Plant 42 and was integrated with the Air Force Systems Command 6510th Test Squadron.

Later operations 🔗

Since the F-117 became operational in 1983, operations at Groom Lake have continued. The base and its associated runway system were expanded. In 1995, the federal government expanded the exclusionary area around the base.

Legal status 🔗

U.S. government’s positions on Area 51 🔗

The United States government has provided minimal information regarding Area 51. The area surrounding the lake is permanently off-limits to both civilian and normal military air traffic. The United States Geological Survey (USGS) topographic map for the area only shows the long-disused

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Area_51

item.title: Alien abduction
item.description:
Alien Abduction 🔗

Alien abduction, also known as abduction phenomenon, alien abduction syndrome, or UFO abduction, is the subjective experience of individuals reporting being kidnapped by extraterrestrial beings and subjected to physical and psychological experimentation. Those who claim to have been abducted are referred to as “abductees” or “experiencers.” The prevailing scientific and mental health perspective attributes these experiences to factors like suggestibility, sleep paralysis, deception, and psychopathology. Skeptics note similarities between alien descriptions and those in science fiction films.

Overview 🔗

Mainstream scientists generally dismiss claims of literal alien abduction. However, some researchers, like psychiatrist John E. Mack, argue that many abductees are sane individuals. A subculture has developed around the phenomenon, complete with support groups and a detailed mythos involving various alien types (Greys, Reptilians, Nordics) with specific roles and motivations. Some abductees explain the lack of wider awareness as a result of extraterrestrial or governmental cover-ups.

History 🔗

Paleo-abductions 🔗

This section discusses older stories that some UFO researchers, like Jerome Clark, have interpreted as possible early cases of alien abduction, termed “paleo-abductions.” Examples include:

  • A November 27, 1896, report in The Evening Mail of Stockton, California, where Colonel H. G. Shaw claimed he and a friend were harassed by tall, slender humanoids who tried to kidnap them.
  • A 1953 Man to Man Magazine article by Leroy Thorpe, questioning if humans were being captured by flying saucers for experimentation.
  • Harold T. Wilkins’s 1955 publication Flying Saucers Uncensored, which reported the mysterious disappearance of Karl Hunrath and Wilbur Wilkinson, who had claimed contact with aliens, suggesting they might have been abducted.

Two Landmark Cases 🔗

This section highlights two early alien abduction claims that gained significant attention:

  • The Antônio Vilas-Boas case in Brazil in the mid-1950s.
  • The Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1961, which received widespread publicity and was dramatized in a 1975 television film. The Hill incident is considered a prototypical abduction case, introducing the beings later known as the Greys and explicitly identifying an extraterrestrial origin.

Skeptic Peter Rogerson notes that these cases established a template for later abduction reports.

Later Developments 🔗

This section discusses the evolution of the alien abduction phenomenon and the involvement of key figures:

  • R. Leo Sprinkle, a University of Wyoming psychologist, became interested in abductions in the 1960s and linked them to cattle mutilation.
  • Budd Hopkins, an artist interested in UFOs, began using hypnosis in the 1970s to uncover details of abduction experiences, becoming a figurehead in the abductee subculture.
  • The 1980s saw increased mainstream attention, with works by Hopkins, Whitley Strieber, David M. Jacobs, and John E. Mack presenting alien abduction as a plausible experience.
  • Thomas E. Bullard’s comparative analysis of nearly 300 alleged abductees was also published in the 1980s.
  • Jacobs and Hopkins argued that alien abduction was far more common than previously suspected and that aliens were attempting to create human-alien hybrids.

According to Linda Rodriguez McRobbie of the Boston Globe, abduction stories have declined in mainstream media in recent decades. Michael Shermer suggests that camera phones have increased the burden of evidence for such claims.

John E. Mack 🔗

This section focuses on Harvard psychiatry professor John E. Mack, who believed in the credibility of alien abduction claims. Niall Boyce, writing in The Lancet, criticized Mack for uncritically elaborating on abduction tales and potentially creating false memories. Mack interviewed over 800 people and wrote two books on the subject, but his professional reputation suffered as a result.

Abductees 🔗

This section discusses the demographics and mental health of alleged abductees. The precise number of abductees is uncertain, with estimates ranging from 1,700 claimants in early studies to 5–6 percent of the general population in contested surveys.

Demographics 🔗

Reports are usually made by adults, but sometimes young children report similar experiences. These child-reports often feature very specific details in common with reports of abduction made by adults, including the circumstances, narrative, entities and aftermaths of the alleged occurrences. Often, these young abductees have family members who have reported having abduction experiences. Family involvement in the military, or a residence near a military base is also common among child abduction claimants.

Mental Health 🔗

Some studies suggest that abductees have psychological characteristics that render their testimony suspect, while others show that “as a group, abduction experients are not different from the general population in term of psychopathology prevalence”. Elizabeth Slater conducted a blind study of nine abduction claimants and found them to be prone to “mildly paranoid thinking”, nightmares and having a weak sexual identity, while Richard McNally of Harvard Medical School concluded in a similar study of 10 abductees that “none of them was suffering from any sort of psychiatric illness.”

Political Conspiracy Theories 🔗

This section explores the connections between radical politics and conspiracy theories involving UFOs, alien visitation, and government cover-ups. Political scientist Michael Barkun highlights the rise of “improvisional millenarism” and the role of UFO and abduction stories in stigmatized knowledge narratives. He notes the emergence of alien-related conspiracy theories in far-right politics from the 1980s onwards. TV shows like The X-Files are mentioned as examples of popular culture incorporating alien conspiracies. Jodi Dean notes that the stigma of alien abduction stories is seductive to dismiss “consensus reality” in favor of deviant alternative realities. Self-described abduction victims may join self-help communities and espouse conspiracy theories involving mind control and a New World Order.

Abduction Narrative 🔗

This section outlines the common elements and sequence of events reported in abduction narratives. According to CUFOS’s definition of abductee, the person must have been taken against their will by apparent non-human beings, taken to a special place perceived as extraterrestrial or to be a spaceship. They then must experience being subjected to an examination or to engage in some form of communication with the beings (or both). Communication may be perceived as telepathic rather than verbal. The memory of the experience may be conscious or “recovered” through means like hypnosis.

Thomas E. Bullard argues that there is a broad, fairly consistent sequence and description of events that make up the typical “close encounter of the fourth kind.” These events include:

  1. Capture: The abductee is rendered incapable of resisting and taken to an alien spacecraft.
  2. Examination and Procedures: Invasive physiological and psychological procedures.
  3. Conference: Communication with the abductors, typically telepathically.
  4. Tour: A tour of the captors’ vessel.
  5. Loss of Time: Rapid forgetting of the experience.
  6. Return: Return to Earth, sometimes in a different location.
  7. Theophany: A profound sense of love or a mystical experience.
  8. Aftermath: Coping with the psychological, physical, and social effects of the experience.

David M. Jacobs emphasizes the orchestrated nature of the abduction event.

Capture 🔗

Abduction claimants report unusual feelings preceding the onset of an abduction experience. These feelings manifest as a compulsive desire to be at a certain place at a certain time or as expectations that something “familiar yet unknown” will soon occur. Abductees also report feeling severe, undirected anxiety at this point even though nothing unusual has actually occurred yet. Eventually, the experiencer will undergo an apparent “shift” into an altered state of consciousness. As consciousness shifts one or more lights are alleged to appear, occasionally accompanied by a strange mist. As the alleged abduction proceeds, claimants say they will walk or be levitated into an alien craft, in the latter case often through solid objects such as walls, ceilings or a closed window.

Examination 🔗

The examination phase is characterized by medical procedures and examinations performed by alien beings against the will of the experiencer. These procedures often focus on sex and reproductive biology. John G. Miller notes differences between human medicine and what is reported as being practiced by the abductors.

Subsequent Procedures 🔗

After the medical exam, abductees often report other procedures, including imaging, envisioning, staging, and testing.

  • “Imaging” involves viewing screens displaying emotionally provocative images.
  • “Envisioning” involves images projected into the experiencer’s mind.
  • “Staging” involves the abductee interacting with an illusionary scenario.
  • “Testing” involves operating a complicated electronic device.

Child Presentation 🔗

Abductees sometimes report being shown a “child” who appears to be a hybrid between humans and their abductors. Thomas E. Bullard could not identify a child presentation phase in the abduction narrative, even after undertaking a study of 300 abduction reports.

Less Common Elements 🔗

Bullard’s study of 300 abduction reports also identified less prominent aspects of the claims, including:

  1. The conference
  2. The tour
  3. The journey
  4. Theophany

These episodes tend to happen between the medical examination and the return.

Return 🔗

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_abduction

item.title: Alien Autopsy (1995 television film)
item.description:
Alien Autopsy (1995 television film) 🔗

This article discusses the 1995 pseudo-documentary Alien Autopsy: Fact or Fiction, which featured footage purporting to show an alien autopsy conducted after the Roswell incident. The program, hosted by Jonathan Frakes, aired on Fox and other networks worldwide, sparking intense debate before being thoroughly debunked as a hoax.

Production 🔗

This section details the production of the Alien Autopsy footage. Ray Santilli and Gary Shoefield admitted to creating the footage in a 2006 documentary. The simulated autopsy was filmed in a London living room using fabricated alien bodies constructed by artist John Humphreys. The alien bodies were made of plaster casts filled with offal, sheep brains, and raspberry jam. Alien artifacts were also created by Humphreys. A homeless man was paid to pose as the original cameraman.

In popular culture 🔗

This section outlines how Alien Autopsy was received and referenced in popular culture. The footage was derided in the media and satirized in The X-Files. In 1998, Fox aired a special debunking the footage. A fictionalized version of the creation and release of the footage was retold in the comedy film Alien Autopsy (2006).

References 🔗

This section lists the sources cited in the article, including books, news articles, and documentaries.

Further reading 🔗

This section provides a list of additional resources for readers interested in learning more about the Alien Autopsy film and the surrounding controversy.

External links 🔗

This section includes links to external websites related to the film, including an article by Ray Santilli and a link to the film on YouTube.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Autopsy_(1995_film)

item.title: Cattle mutilation
item.description:
Cattle Mutilation 🔗

Cattle mutilation refers to the killing and mutilation of cattle (and other animals) under unusual and often bloodless circumstances. The phenomenon is often linked to paranormal or supernatural explanations, including cults, government agencies, cryptids like the chupacabra, and extraterrestrials. The article notes that similar mutilations have been observed in other livestock and wild animals, with specific body parts often removed. Two independent federal investigations in the United States have been conducted on the topic.

Early History 🔗

The earliest documented outbreak of unexplained livestock deaths occurred in England in 1606. Later, Charles Fort collected accounts of cattle mutilations in England during the late 19th and early 20th centuries.

The “Snippy” Horse Death of 1967 🔗

This section focuses on the 1967 case of a horse named “Snippy” found mutilated in Alamosa, Colorado. The Pueblo Chieftain published the initial story. The horse’s head and neck were skinned and defleshed, and the body displayed precise cuts. No blood was present, and a medicinal odor was reported. This case was the first to link extraterrestrials and UFOs to mutilations. Wadsworth Ayer investigated the case for the Condon Committee and concluded there was no evidence of abnormal causes. Sheriff Ben Phillips suggested a lightning strike as the cause. Two students later confessed to shooting the horse.

Cattle Mutilations 1973–1980 🔗

This section covers a wave of cattle mutilations reported in Kansas, Nebraska, Colorado, and New Mexico during the 1970s.

1973 Kansas Wave 🔗

In June 1973, Cloud County sheriff Fred Modlin warned the public about suspicious phone calls from someone posing as a USDA official. A series of butchered cows were found on farms in Cloud County, with right ears removed. Local press speculated about a “Mad Dog” or “phantom” butcher. By December, law enforcement reported a wave of cattle deaths in seven counties across Kansas and Nebraska, with sexual organs removed. State Senator Ross Doyen reported a mutilation on his ranch. The Kansas Brand Commissioner’s office attributed most deaths to natural causes, but Modlin disagreed.

1974 Nebraska Wave 🔗

Reports resumed in April 1974, with a Nebraska cow found mutilated and drained of blood. The North American Newspaper Alliance reported on the 1973 mutilations and helicopter sightings. In May, mutilations were reported in Mills County, Iowa, with coyotes suggested as the cause. By June, mutilations were reported in Lancaster County, Nebraska. Custer County reported helicopter sightings and armed patrols. An unidentified helicopter was spotted hovering above a field where a mutilated cow was later found near Agnew, Nebraska. Knox County Sheriff Herbert Thompson reported armed civilian patrols. Cloud County Attorney William Walsh suggested devil-worshiping cultists were responsible. State Sen. John Decamp called for a coordinated investigation. By August 28, 25 mutilations were reported across five Nebraska counties. A rancher near Hartington apparently thwarted a mutilation in progress when he spotted a helicopter. Authorities cautioned the public not to shoot at aircraft. Over 50 law enforcement officials attended a meeting in Center, Nebraska, to discuss the mutilations. Three cases of alleged mutilations were reported in South Dakota. Newsweek became the first national outlet to cover the story. South Dakota Attorney General Kermit Sande reported mutilations in the state. UFO expert J. Allen Hynek denied any link between UFOs and mutilations. Mutilations were also reported in Minnesota.

1975 Colorado 🔗

In 1975, the Colorado Associated Press voted the mutilations as the state’s top story. Senator Floyd K. Haskell contacted the FBI for help, claiming 130 mutilations in Colorado and reports across nine states. A 1979 FBI report indicated an estimated 8,000 mutilations in Colorado, causing approximately $1 million in damages. Donald E. Flickinger of the Michigan ATF investigated possible links to a “Hell-oriented biker gang.” The Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. The New York Times published a story examining cattle mutilations across 11 states.

1976 Dulce, New Mexico 🔗

On June 13, 1976, Dulce rancher Manuel Gomez reported a mutilation to Officer Gabe Valdez of the New Mexico State Patrol.

1979 Public Meeting 🔗

On April 20, 1979, U.S. Attorney R. E. Thompson and US Senator Harrison Schmidt held a public meeting about cattle mutilations. Paul Bennewitz reported seeing unidentified lights over Kirtland Air Force Base. Gabe Valdez reported finding two drugs in the remains of a mutilated bull, one to tranquilize the animal and another to remove blood. On June 14, 1981, investigators found a mutilated cow at the Gomez ranch with radar chaff nearby.

Later Incidents 🔗

Many cases of mutilation have been reported worldwide since 1967, chiefly in the Americas and Australia. In South America, an estimated 3,500 incidents have occurred since 2002. In 1993, photographic evidence surfaced of a mutilated male human corpse found near the Guarapiranga reservoir of São Paulo, Brazil, in 1988.

Characteristics 🔗

Cattle deaths due to natural causes are extremely common. Unusual cattle deaths are characterized by the absence of sex organs, udders, tongues, anus, rectum, and sometimes ears or eyes. Cuts are described as “clean” and “surgical.” Some animals are reported to have been drained of blood. Nearly 90 percent of mutilated cattle are between four and five years old. Strange marks or imprints near the site have been found.

Laboratory Reports 🔗

Laboratory reports on some mutilated animals have shown unusual levels of vitamins or minerals and the presence of chemicals not normally found in animals. In one case documented by New Mexico police and the FBI, an 11-month-old bull belonging to Manuel Gomez of Dulce, New Mexico, was found mutilated in 1978. The animal’s heart, bone, and muscle samples were sent to the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory, while liver samples were sent to private laboratories. The liver was found to be completely devoid of copper and to contain high levels of zinc, potassium, and phosphorus. Blood samples were reported to be light pink and did not clot.

Helicopter Sightings 🔗

On July 15, 1974, two unregistered helicopters reportedly opened fire on Robert Smith Jr. in Honey Creek, Iowa. On August 20, 1974, the Lincoln Journal Star reported residents seeing unidentified helicopters shining spotlights into fields where mutilated cows were later found. By 1975, some ranchers formed armed vigilante groups. In 1976, two Cache County, Utah, police officers reportedly confronted men in an unmarked U.S. Army helicopter. On April 8, 1979, three police officers in Dulce, New Mexico, reported a mysterious aircraft resembling a U.S. military helicopter.

Official Investigations 🔗

The New Mexico Livestock Board sought assistance from the Los Alamos Scientific Laboratory. Colorado Bureau of Investigation agents went undercover. Oklahoma convened a task force. Federal authorities launched a comprehensive investigation.

Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms 🔗

In January 1975, the Minnesota field office of the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms (ATF) launched an investigation headed by Agent Donald Flickinger to investigate possible connections between cults and cattle mutilation. Flickinger recorded unusual incidents but found insufficient evidence of cult involvement.

Colorado Bureau of Investigation 🔗

In May 1975, the Colorado Bureau of Investigation opened an investigation under Carl Whiteside. 19 animals underwent necropsies at Colorado State University, but no conclusive results emerged. The US Bureau of Land Management grounded all helicopters in Eastern Colorado. By December, the CBI had investigated 203 reports of cattle mutilations.

New Mexico State Police 🔗

On June 13, 1976, the New Mexico State Police began an investigation headed by Officer Gabe Valdez. Valdez solicited the assistance of retired Sandia National Laboratories scientist Howard Burgess. On the night of July 5, suspecting that cattle might be “marked,” Burgess and Valdez screened the Gomez herd and found five animals marked with a chemical that fluoresced under ultraviolet light. On June 14, 1981, intact radar chaff was found near a mutilated cow on the Gomez ranch. This investigation reported finding evidence that some mutilated animals had been tranquilized and treated with an anti-coagulant.

Rommel Investigation 🔗

Beginning in May 1979, an investigation was funded by a grant from the Law Enforcement Assistance Administration and headed by retired FBI agent Kenneth Rommel. The report concluded that the mutilations were predominantly the result of natural predation, but some cases contained anomalies.

Conventional Explanations 🔗

Potential explanations for cattle mutilations range from death by natural causes to purposeful acts by unknown individuals.

On April 20, 1979, C Hibbs of the New Mexico State Veterinary diagnostics Laboratory testified that mutilation fell into three categories: natural causes, deaths caused by pranksters or deviants, and animals mutilated with “sharp instruments”.

Natural Causes 🔗

Missing or mutilated mouth, lips, anus, and genitalia are explained as contraction of missing/damaged areas

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cattle_mutilation

item.title: UFO conspiracy theories
item.description:
UFO Conspiracy Theories 🔗

This Wikipedia entry delves into the world of UFO conspiracy theories, exploring the belief that governments, particularly the United States government, are suppressing evidence of extraterrestrial life and technology. It examines the historical development of these theories, their proponents, and their presence in popular culture and religion.

Overview 🔗

This section introduces the core concept of UFO conspiracy theories: the alleged suppression of evidence regarding extraterrestrial-controlled UFOs or technology. It notes the evolution of these theories, from initial claims of government cover-ups to more complex narratives involving communication and cooperation with extraterrestrials, including claims of government allowance of cattle mutilation and alien abduction. It also mentions the Committee for Skeptical Inquiry’s stance that there is little to no evidence supporting these theories.

Mainstream Views 🔗

This section presents the mainstream scientific perspective on UFOs. It acknowledges the historical and cultural prominence of UFO sightings, particularly after World War II and during the Space Age. It highlights government and independent investigations that have failed to confirm extraordinary claims made by ufologists. Prosaic explanations for UFO sightings, such as natural phenomena, human technology, delusions, and hoaxes, are offered. The section also touches upon the psychosocial explanations for UFO beliefs and their influence on new religions. Benjamin Radford’s argument about the unlikelihood of a decades-long, international cover-up is also presented.

Notable Proponents 🔗

This section identifies key figures associated with UFO conspiracy theories. Donald Keyhoe, Jacque Vallee, J. Allen Hynek, and Stanton Friedman are mentioned as prominent voices from the 1950s to the 1970s. It also notes that some early proponents, like Richard Shaver and Paul Bennewitz, suffered from psychiatric issues, and that some proponents confessed to hoaxes or lies. The section lists individuals in positions of authority, such as Senator Barry Goldwater, Admiral Lord Hill-Norton, Vice Admiral Roscoe H. Hillenkoetter, and astronauts Gordon Cooper and Edgar Mitchell, who have suggested that UFO evidence is being suppressed. 21st-century proponents like Paul Hellyer, Garry Nolan, Haim Eshed, Jim Semivan, Harold E. Puthoff, Tom DeLonge, Luis Elizondo, and David Grusch are also mentioned.

In Popular Fiction 🔗

This section explores the portrayal of government cover-ups of extraterrestrial contact in popular fiction. Films like 2001: A Space Odyssey, Easy Rider, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, E.T. the Extra-Terrestrial, Flight of the Navigator, Total Recall, Independence Day, and Men in Black are cited as examples. Television series such as The X-Files, Dark Skies, and Stargate are also mentioned. The section also notes John Glenn’s appearance on Frasier, Sidney Sheldon’s novel The Doomsday Conspiracy, and the series American Horror Story: Double Feature.

In Religion 🔗

This section examines the intersection of UFO conspiracy theories and religion. It identifies new religious movements, including the Nation of Islam, Scientology, and Heaven’s Gate, that have incorporated UFO-related beliefs. Mormon cosmology, Theosophy, and the “I AM” Activity are also discussed. The section mentions the Nation of Islam’s concept of “The Mother Plane,” the UFO religions Unarius and the Aetherius Society, L. Ron Hubbard’s teachings about Xenu in Scientology, and the Raëlism movement. It concludes with the Heaven’s Gate mass suicide and the Order of the Solar Temple mass deaths.

Chronology of UFO Conspiracy Theories 🔗

This section provides a detailed timeline of the development of UFO conspiracy theories, starting with Raymond Palmer’s pulp magazine Amazing Stories in the 1940s.

1940s Origin in Raymond Palmer’s Pulp Magazine 🔗

This subsection focuses on Raymond Palmer, the editor of Amazing Stories, and his role in popularizing UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions his publication of Richard Shaver’s stories about a secret underground race and Palmer’s claim that world governments were aware of spaceships visiting Earth.

Spaceships of “The Shaver Mystery” 🔗

This subsection details Richard Shaver’s claims of telepathic communication with a secret underground race and their mastery of space travel. It notes Shaver’s history of psychiatric problems and the blurring of fact and fiction in his stories.

Kenneth Arnold Ignites Flying Disc Craze 🔗

This subsection covers the beginning of the flying disc craze with Kenneth Arnold’s sighting in 1947. It mentions the Roswell incident and the Army’s initial press release about recovering a “flying disc.” It also discusses Palmer’s investigation of Fred Crisman’s claims near Maury Island, Washington, and the subsequent plane crash.

Aftermath 🔗

This subsection describes the aftermath of the Maury Island incident and the continued promotion of UFO conspiracy theories by Palmer and Shaver. It mentions Shaver’s “rock books” and Palmer’s later admission that Shaver had spent time in a mental institution. It also notes Palmer’s claim of a link between flying saucers, the Shaver Mystery, the Kennedy assassination, Watergate, and Fred Crisman.

National Coverage in the 1950s 🔗

This section discusses the increase in governmental and civilian investigative efforts and reports of public disinformation and suppression of evidence in the 1950s.

The Flying Saucer Conspiracy 🔗

This subsection focuses on Donald Keyhoe’s role in promoting UFO conspiracy theories in the 1950s. It mentions his article “The Flying Saucers Are Real” and his book The Flying Saucer Conspiracy, which accused the government of covering up knowledge of flying saucers. It also describes Keyhoe’s appearance on CBS’s Armstrong Circle Theatre and the cutting of his microphone during the live broadcast.

Aztec “Alien Bodies” Hoax 🔗

This subsection details the Frank Scully’s “alien bodies” conspiracy theory, which claimed that dead extraterrestrial beings were recovered from a flying saucer crash. It mentions Scully’s book Behind the Flying Saucers and the later exposure of Scully as a victim of confidence artists.

Air Force Accounts 🔗

This subsection covers the Air Force’s response to UFO sightings in the 1950s. It mentions General John Samford’s press conference on the Washington D.C. UFO incident, the Robertson Panel’s recommendation for public education, and Al Chop’s role as the press spokesman for Project Bluebook. It also discusses Captain Edward J. Ruppelt’s book The Report on Unidentified Flying Objects.

“Philadelphia Experiment” Hoax 🔗

This subsection describes the “Philadelphia Experiment” hoax, which involved claims of a navy ship being made invisible and teleporting. It mentions Morris K. Jessup’s book The Case for the UFO and the letters he received from “Carlos Miguel Allende” (Carl Meredith Allen). It also discusses the annotated copy of Jessup’s book and Jessup’s death by suicide.

‘Men in Black’ Legends 🔗

This subsection explores the legend of the Men in Black, popularized by Gray Barker’s book They Knew Too Much About Flying Saucers. It mentions the speculation that the men in black are government agents who harass and threaten UFO witnesses.

1960-70s: Growing Distrust in Government 🔗

This section discusses the growing government skepticism in the 1960s and 1970s, fueled by events like the Kennedy assassination, the Pentagon Papers, and the Watergate scandal.

Michigan “Swamp Gas” UFO Reports 🔗

This subsection covers the 1966 UFO reports in Michigan and the Air Force’s explanation that they were caused by swamp gas. It notes the ridicule that followed and the call for a Congressional investigation.

Fred Crisman and JFK Conspiracy Theories 🔗

This subsection details Fred Crisman’s involvement in the JFK assassination conspiracy theories. It mentions Jim Garrison’s prosecution of Clay Shaw and Crisman’s testimony before the New Orleans grand jury.

“Cosmic Watergate” 🔗

This subsection explores the concept of a “Cosmic Watergate,” referring to a government cover-up of UFO information. It mentions the film 2001: A Space Odyssey and J. Allen Hynek’s claim that Bluebook was a “Cosmic Watergate.”

Alien Bodies at “Hangar 18” 🔗

This subsection discusses the legends of alien bodies being stored at “Hangar 18” at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base. It mentions Robert Spencer Carr’s claim that alien bodies recovered from the Aztec crash were stored there.

“Alien Abductions” 🔗

This subsection covers the rise of alien abduction claims in the 1970s. It mentions the Betty and Barney Hill case, the Travis Walton incident, and the work of Budd Hopkins and Whitley Strieber.

Close Encounters of the Third Kind 🔗

This subsection explores the influence of the film Close Encounters of the Third Kind on UFO conspiracy theories. It mentions the film’s depiction of a government cover-up and the involvement of J. Allen Hynek and Jacques Vallee.

Jesse Marcel and Roswell 🔗

This subsection details Jesse Marcel’s role in the Roswell incident and his later statements suggesting that the debris might have been extraterrestrial. It mentions the National Enquirer’s coverage of the story and the US military’s later reports disclosing the true nature of the crashed aircraft.

Doty and Lear Promote the “Dark Side 🔗

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/UFO_conspiracy_theories

item.title: Grey alien
item.description:
Grey Aliens 🔗

Grey aliens, also known as Zeta Reticulans, Roswell Greys, or simply Greys, are alleged extraterrestrial beings frequently featured in close encounter and alien abduction claims. They are typically depicted as small humanoids with grey skin, large heads, and black, almond-shaped eyes. The Barney and Betty Hill abduction case in 1961 is credited with popularizing the Grey alien image. These beings have become an archetypal representation of intelligent non-human creatures and extraterrestrial life in popular culture.

Description 🔗

This section details the typical physical characteristics attributed to Grey aliens. They are generally described as diminutive humanoid beings with grey skin and reduced or absent external human features like noses, ears, or sex organs. Their bodies are elongated with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. They have disproportionately large heads, no hair, and small openings for ears, nostrils, and mouths. Their most striking feature is their large, opaque, black eyes.

Appearance 🔗

This subsection elaborates on the physical appearance of Greys. They are typically depicted as grey-skinned, small humanoids with reduced or absent external human body parts. Their bodies are elongated, with small chests, lacking muscular definition and visible skeletal structure. Their legs are shorter and jointed differently from humans. They have unusually large heads in proportion to their bodies, no hair, and no noticeable outer ears or noses. They are almost always shown with very large, opaque, black eyes, without eye whites, and are frequently described as shorter than average adult humans.

Association with Zeta Reticuli 🔗

This subsection explains the connection between Grey aliens and the Zeta Reticuli star system. The association originated with Marjorie Fish’s interpretation of a map drawn by Betty Hill in 1969. Hill, under hypnosis, claimed to have been shown a map displaying the aliens’ home system and nearby stars. Fish created a model from Hill’s drawing and determined that the stars marked as the aliens’ home were Zeta Reticuli, a binary star system.

History 🔗

This section traces the origins and evolution of the Grey alien archetype. Descriptions of beings similar to Greys predate claims of encounters with them. H.G. Wells described humans with similar features in his writings from the late 19th century. Aleister Crowley described a meeting with a similar entity named Lam as early as 1917. Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, described similar aliens in his 1933 science fiction novel The Unknown Danger.

Origins 🔗

This subsection details the literary and occult origins of the Grey alien archetype. In 1893, H.G. Wells described humanity’s future appearance as lacking mouths, noses, or hair, and with large heads. In 1895, Wells depicted the Eloi in similar terms in The Time Machine. As early as 1917, Aleister Crowley described a meeting with a “preternatural entity” named Lam, similar in appearance to a modern Grey. In 1933, Gustav Sandgren, writing as Gabriel Linde, published The Unknown Danger, describing extraterrestrials with grey fabric clothes, short stature, big bald heads, and large, dark, gleaming eyes.

Barney and Betty Hill abduction 🔗

This subsection focuses on the Barney and Betty Hill abduction case and its role in popularizing the Grey alien archetype. Newspaper reports of the Betty and Barney Hill abduction in 1965 made the archetype famous. The Hills claimed that in 1961, grey-skinned humanoid alien beings abducted them and took them to a flying saucer. Martin Kottmeyer suggested that Barney’s memories might have been influenced by an episode of The Outer Limits titled “The Bellero Shield.” Carl Sagan echoed Kottmeyer’s suspicions, citing Invaders from Mars as another potential inspiration.

Diffusion into folklore 🔗

This subsection discusses how Greys became an integral part of ufology and extraterrestrial-related folklore after the Hills’ encounter. According to journalist C.D.B. Bryan, 73% of all reported alien encounters in the United States describe Grey aliens. In the early 1980s, Greys were linked to the alleged crash-landing of a flying saucer in Roswell, New Mexico, in 1947. In 1987, Whitley Strieber published the book Communion, describing his alleged close encounters with Greys and other extraterrestrial beings. In 1988, Jimmy Guieu described “the little greys” on French television. In 1995, Ray Santilli claimed to have obtained film footage depicting the autopsy of a “real” Grey recovered from the Roswell incident.

Analysis 🔗

This section explores various analyses and interpretations of the Grey alien phenomenon.

In close encounter claims and ufology 🔗

This subsection examines the role of Greys in alien abduction claims and ufology. Greys are often involved in alien abduction claims, making up about 50% of reports in Australia, 73% in the United States, 48% in continental Europe, and around 12% in the United Kingdom. These reports include two distinct groups of Greys that differ in height. Abduction claims are often described as extremely traumatic. The eyes are often a focus of abduction claims, with Greys staring into the eyes of abductees when conducting mental procedures.

Psychocultural expression of intelligence 🔗

This subsection presents neurologist Steven Novella’s theory that Grey aliens are a byproduct of the human imagination, with their distinctive features representing everything that modern humans traditionally link with intelligence.

The “Mother Hypothesis” 🔗

This subsection introduces Frederick V. Malmstrom’s idea that Greys are actually residual memories of early childhood development. Malmstrom reconstructs the face of a Grey through transformation of a mother’s face based on our best understanding of early-childhood sensation and perception.

Evolutionary implausibility 🔗

This subsection presents biologist Jack Cohen’s argument that the typical image of a Grey is too physiologically similar to a human to be credible as a representation of an alien from a world with different environmental and ecological conditions.

Other hypotheses 🔗

This subsection mentions alternative explanations for the humanoid anatomy and behavior of alleged Grey aliens, including the interdimensional hypothesis, the cryptoterrestrial hypothesis, and the time-traveler hypothesis.

In popular culture 🔗

This section discusses the prevalence of Grey aliens in popular culture. Depictions of Grey aliens have appeared in numerous films and television shows, supplanting the previously popular little green men. Examples include Ultraman, Close Encounters of the Third Kind, Babylon 5, Stargate, and South Park. During the 1990s, plotlines wherein Greys were linked to conspiracy theories became common, such as in The X-Files. Other examples include the XCOM video game franchise, Dark Skies, and American Dad!. The 2011 film Paul tells the story of a Grey named Paul who attributes the Greys’ frequent presence in science fiction pop culture to the US government deliberately inserting the stereotypical Grey alien image into mainstream media. Child abduction by Greys is a key plot point in the 2013 film, Dark Skies. Greys appear in Syfy’s 2021 science fiction dramedy series Resident Alien. The Greys appear as the main antagonistic faction in the 2023 independent game Greyhill Incident.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Grey_alien

item.title: Nordic aliens
item.description:
Nordic Aliens 🔗

In ufology, “Nordics,” “Nordic aliens,” or “Tall Whites” are terms used to describe alleged humanoid extraterrestrials who purportedly resemble Nordic, Germanic, or Scandinavian humans. They are said to originate from the Pleiades star cluster and are often described by contactees as being taller than average humans (6-7 ft), with blond hair, blue eyes, and fair skin. Some reports also mention pale-blue/grey or pastel purple skin tones.

History 🔗

Early stories of Nordic aliens may have been inspired by the 1951 film The Day the Earth Stood Still. Within the ufology community, these aliens are often associated with spiritual growth, benevolence, and protection. They are described as concerned about Earth’s ecology and world peace, possessing telepathic abilities, and exhibiting paternal, watchful, affectionate, and youthful characteristics. While popular in the 1950s, claims of encounters with Nordic aliens have become less frequent, with the grey alien becoming more prominent in reported extraterrestrial encounters. David J. Skal, a cultural historian, and Stephanie Kelley-Romano, a professor at Bates College, are mentioned in relation to their perspectives on Nordic aliens.

Publications by Those Claiming to Have Been Contacted 🔗

Several books detail alleged personal contact with Nordic aliens. These include Flying Saucers Have Landed and Inside the Space Ships by George Adamski, From Outer Space to You by Howard Menger, The Walton Experience by Travis Walton, and Millennial Hospitality by Charles James Hall, which was adapted into the film Walking with the Tall Whites. The UFO religion Universe People also publishes interactions with “Cosmic Friends.”

See Also 🔗

This section lists related topics and figures in ufology, including:

  • Space Brothers
  • Truman Bethurum
  • Elizabeth Klarer
  • Billy Meier
  • Linda Moulton Howe
  • List of alleged extraterrestrial beings
  • Star people (New Age)
  • Arcturians (New Age)
  • UFOs
  • UFO religion

References 🔗

This section lists the references used in the article, including books and articles by Debbora Battaglia, C. D. B. Bryan, Jerome Clark, Una McGovern, Stephanie Kelley-Romano, David Skal, Desmond Leslie, George Adamski, Howard Menger, Travis Walton, Charles James Hall, and links to external websites.

External Links 🔗

This section provides a link to Wikimedia Commons for media related to Nordic aliens.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nordic_aliens

item.title: White Orb Watches Family BBQ Over Lakeland, Florida
item.description:
An eyewitness at a family BBQ were enjoying the day when someone pointed out a white orb in the sky above. Then others came and they noticed it stayed over them as if it were watching them and recording the humans reactions to what they were seeing. You see, aliens love knowledge, like humans like money, knowledge is everything to them. The smaller orb drones are sent out from a mother drone and months later gathered after the orbs have recorded information about anything and everything they saw.

item.title: Alien Hive
item.description:
Alien Hive 🔗

Alien Hive is a puzzle video game developed and published by Malaysia-based studio Appxplore in March 2013. It is available on iOS, Android, and Windows Phone platforms. The game combines match-three and sliding puzzle mechanics.

Gameplay 🔗

The gameplay involves swiping tiles to match eggs and aliens, with the goal of hatching, breeding, and evolving them into the Supreme Alien. Players aim to build the ultimate alien hive by matching resource tiles while avoiding Naughty Bots. Power-ups can be crafted to eliminate these troublemakers, and players are encouraged to minimize their moves. As players progress, they encounter more aliens and uncover their mysteries.

Magic Fruit, collected by merging seeds into saplings, is key to evolving Supreme Aliens. These fruits allow merging of similar-level items using only two of a kind instead of three. Evolved Supreme Aliens can be activated using gold to provide special bonuses in future games.

In App Purchase 🔗

Alien Hive incorporates microtransactions, where real money can be exchanged for in-game gold to purchase consumable items. This aspect of the game has faced criticism, with one review suggesting that microtransactions are almost essential.

Reception 🔗

Alien Hive received an average score of 70 out of 100 based on reviews aggregated by Metacritic.

By 2015, the game had achieved over 3 million downloads across all platforms.

References 🔗

This section lists the references cited in the article, including links to sources such as the Appxplore website, the Google Play Store, My Filing Cabinet, GameZEBO, Metacritic, and Vulcan Post. These links provide verification and further information about the game’s details, reviews, and achievements.

External links 🔗

This section provides a link to the official website of Alien Hive.

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Alien_Hive

item.title: Extraterrestrial life
item.description:
Extraterrestrial Life 🔗

Extraterrestrial life, also known as alien life, refers to life that originates from a world other than Earth. While no such life has been conclusively detected, the possibility ranges from simple prokaryotes to intelligent beings and civilizations. The study of extraterrestrial life falls under the domain of astrobiology.

Unsolved problem in astronomy 🔗

The question of whether life exists elsewhere in the universe remains an unsolved problem in astronomy. Key questions include: Could life have arisen elsewhere? What are the requirements for life? Are there exoplanets like Earth? How likely is the evolution of intelligent life?

Speculation about extraterrestrial life 🔗

Speculation about life beyond Earth dates back to antiquity. Early Christian writers discussed the “plurality of worlds,” an idea proposed by thinkers like Democritus. Augustine referenced Epicurus’s concept of innumerable worlds throughout space. Pre-modern writers often assumed extraterrestrial worlds were inhabited. William Vorilong considered the possibility of Jesus visiting other worlds. Nicholas of Cusa theorized that all extraterrestrial bodies, including the Sun, could be inhabited. Descartes acknowledged the speculative nature of intelligent creatures on other stars.

Atmospheric composition and ecosystems 🔗

Compared to Earth, the atmospheric composition and ecosystems of other celestial bodies can make extraterrestrial life seem speculative. However, extreme ecosystems on Earth, such as hydrothermal vents, acidic hot springs, and volcanic lakes, support life under harsh conditions, providing parallels to extreme environments on other planets and supporting the possibility of extraterrestrial life.

Active research 🔗

Since the mid-20th century, active research has sought signs of extraterrestrial life, including current and historic life, and extraterrestrial intelligent life. Methods range from analyzing telescope and specimen data to using radios to detect communications.

Cultural impact 🔗

The concept of extraterrestrial life, especially extraterrestrial intelligence, has significantly impacted culture, particularly in science fiction. Science fiction has communicated scientific ideas, imagined possibilities, and influenced public interest in extraterrestrial life. The debate over communicating with extraterrestrial intelligence continues, with some advocating for aggressive contact methods and others warning of potential dangers.

Context 🔗

This article is part of a series on life in the universe, including planetary habitability in the Solar System (Venus, Earth, Mars, Europa, Enceladus, Titan), life outside the Solar System (habitable zone, potentially habitable exoplanets, galactic habitable zone), and the habitability of binary star systems, natural satellites, neutron star systems, red dwarf systems, K-type main-sequence star systems, yellow dwarf systems, and F-type main-sequence star systems.

Initial conditions 🔗

Initially, the universe was too hot for life after the Big Bang. It cooled to temperate levels 15 million years later, but the elements for life did not yet exist. Carbon and oxygen appeared 50 million years later through stellar fusion. Planetary systems emerged, and organic compounds may have formed in protoplanetary disks. Earth, initially molten, became more receptive to organics after cooling. Life started on Earth through abiogenesis. Alternatively, life may have spread between habitable planets via meteoroids in a process called panspermia.

Stellar evolution 🔗

Stars combine hydrogen nuclei to make helium nuclei through stellar fusion, releasing energy. This process continues until the star exhausts its fuel. In its last stages, stars combine helium nuclei to form carbon nuclei, and higher-sized stars can further combine carbon nuclei to create oxygen and silicon, and so on until iron. The star then blows its content back into the stellar medium, which would join clouds that would eventually become new generations of stars and planets. Many of those materials are the raw components of life on Earth. As this process takes place in all the universe, said materials are ubiquitous in the cosmos and not a rarity from the Solar System.

Location in the universe 🔗

Earth is a planet in the Solar System, which is part of the Milky Way galaxy. The Milky Way is part of the Local Group, a galaxy group within the Laniakea Supercluster. The universe is composed of all similar structures. Immense distances between celestial objects pose a challenge for studying extraterrestrial life. Humans have only set foot on the Moon and sent probes to other planets and moons in the Solar System. Probes face time delays due to distance. No probe has reached extrasolar planetary systems. Voyager 2 has left the Solar System, but would take 100,000 years to reach the Alpha Centauri system. Telescopes have limitations in studying such systems. Dark matter, though abundant, is not usually considered by astrobiology due to its limited role in stellar evolution.

Circumstellar habitable zone 🔗

The circumstellar habitable zone, or “Goldilocks zone,” is the area around a star where water may exist in liquid form on a planetary surface. However, planetary habitability is complex and defined by several factors. Being in the habitable zone is not enough for a planet to be habitable. Venus is located in the habitable zone of the Solar System but does not have liquid water because of the conditions of its atmosphere. Gas giants are not considered habitable even if they orbit close enough to their stars as hot Jupiters, due to crushing atmospheric pressures. The actual distances for the habitable zones vary according to the type of star, and even the solar activity of each specific star influences the local habitability. The type of star also defines the time the habitable zone will exist, as its presence and limits will change along with the star’s stellar evolution.

Cosmic perspective 🔗

The Big Bang occurred 13.8 billion years ago, the Solar System formed 4.6 billion years ago, and the first hominids appeared 6 million years ago. Life on other planets may have started, evolved, given birth to extraterrestrial intelligences, and perhaps even faced a planetary extinction event millions or even billions of years ago. The brief times of existence of Earth’s species, when considered from a cosmic perspective, may suggest that extraterrestrial life may be equally fleeting under such a scale.

Habitable Epoch of the Early Universe 🔗

During a period of about 7 million years, from about 10 to 17 million after the Big Bang, the background temperature was between 373 and 273 K (100 and 0 °C; 212 and 32 °F), allowing the possibility of liquid water if any planets existed. Avi Loeb speculated that primitive life might have appeared during this window, which he called “the Habitable Epoch of the Early Universe”.

Ubiquitous life 🔗

Life on Earth is ubiquitous and has adapted to almost all available environments. Extremophiles and the deep biosphere thrive even in hostile conditions. It is inferred that life in other celestial bodies may be equally adaptive. However, the origin of life is unrelated to its ease of adaptation and may have stricter requirements. A celestial body may not have any life on it, even if it were habitable.

Likelihood of existence 🔗

It is unclear if life, and more importantly, intelligent life in the cosmos is ubiquitous or rare. The hypothesis of ubiquitous extraterrestrial life relies on three main ideas: the size and age of the universe, the ubiquity of chemical elements that make up life, and the universality of physical laws. Scientists such as Carl Sagan and Stephen Hawking argue that it would be improbable for life not to exist somewhere other than Earth. This argument is embodied in the Copernican principle and the mediocrity principle.

Rare Earth hypothesis 🔗

Other authors consider that life in the cosmos, or at least multicellular life, may be rare. The Rare Earth hypothesis maintains that life on Earth is possible because of a series of factors that range from the location in the galaxy and the configuration of the Solar System to local characteristics of the planet, and that it is unlikely that all such requirements are simultaneously met by another planet. Proponents of this hypothesis consider that very little evidence suggests the existence of extraterrestrial life and that at this point it is just a desired result and not a reasonable scientific explanation for any gathered data.

Drake equation 🔗

In 1961, astronomer and astrophysicist Frank Drake devised the Drake equation as a way to stimulate scientific dialogue at a meeting on the search for extraterrestrial intelligence (SETI). The Drake equation is a probabilistic argument used to estimate the number of active, communicative extraterrestrial civilizations in the Milky Way galaxy.

Hubble Space Telescope 🔗

Based on observations from the Hubble Space Telescope, there are nearly 2 trillion galaxies in the observable universe. It is estimated that at least ten percent of all Sun-like stars have a system of planets, i.e. there are 6.25×1018 stars with planets orbiting them in the observable universe. Even if it is assumed that only one out of a billion of these stars has planets supporting life, there would be some 6.25 billion life-supporting planetary systems in the observable universe. A 2013 study based on results from the Kepler spacecraft estimated that the Milky Way contains at least as many planets as it does stars, resulting in 100–400 billion exoplanets.

Nebular hypothesis 🔗

The Nebular hypothesis that explains the formation of the Solar System and other planetary systems would suggest that those can have several configurations, and not all of them may have rocky planets within the habitable zone.

Fermi paradox 🔗

The apparent contradiction between high estimates of the probability of the existence of extraterrestrial civilizations and the lack of evidence for such civilizations is known as the Fermi paradox. Dennis W. Sciama claimed that life’s existence in the universe depends on various fundamental constants. Zhi-Wei Wang and Samuel L. Braunstein suggest that a random universe capable of supporting life is likely

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Extraterrestrial_life

item.title: Crop circle
item.description:
Crop Circle 🔗

A crop circle, also known as a crop formation or corn circle, is a pattern created by flattening a crop, usually a cereal. The term was coined in the early 1980s. While fringe theorists suggest obscure natural causes or alien origins, there is no scientific evidence for such explanations, and all crop circles are consistent with human causation. In 1991, Doug Bower and Dave Chorley, two hoaxers, claimed responsibility for creating over 200 crop circles throughout England. Reported circles in the United Kingdom appear near roads, areas of medium to dense population, and cultural heritage monuments, such as Stonehenge or Avebury, and usually appear overnight. Archaeological remains can cause cropmarks in the fields in the shapes of circles and squares, but these do not appear overnight, and are always in the same places every year.

History 🔗

Before the 20th century 🔗

A 1678 news pamphlet The Mowing-Devil: or, Strange News Out of Hartfordshire describes a crop whose stalks were cut rather than bent. In 1686, English naturalist Robert Plot reported on rings or arcs of mushrooms in The Natural History of Stafford-Shire, proposing air flows from the sky as a cause. In 1991, meteorologist Terence Meaden linked this report with modern crop circles. An 1880 letter to the editor of Nature by amateur scientist John Rand Capron describes how several circles of flattened crops in a field were formed under suspicious circumstances and possibly caused by “cyclonic wind action”.

20th century 🔗

In 1932, archaeologist E. C. Curwen observed four dark rings in a field at Stoughton Down near Chichester. In Fortean Times, David Wood reported that in 1940 he made crop circles near Gloucestershire using ropes. In 1963, Patrick Moore described a crater in a potato field in Wiltshire and several circular and elliptical areas in nearby wheat fields. Astronomer Hugh Ernest Butler observed similar craters and said they were likely caused by lightning strikes. During the 1960s, there were many reports of UFO sightings and circular formations in swamp reeds and sugarcane fields in Tully, Queensland, Australia, and in Canada. On 8 August 1967, three circles were found in a field in Duhamel, Alberta, Canada; Department of National Defence investigators concluded that it was artificial. The most famous case is the 1966 Tully “saucer nest”. British pranksters Doug Bower and Dave Chorley reported they started creating crop circles in British cornfields in 1978, inspired by the Tully “saucer nest” case. The first film to depict a geometric crop circle, in this case created by super-intelligent ants, was the 1974 science-fiction film Phase IV. The majority of reports of crop circles have appeared and spread since the late 1970s. By 2001, approximately 10,000 crop circles have been reported internationally.

21st century 🔗

Since the start of the 21st century, crop formations have increased in size and complexity. The researcher Jeremy Northcote found that crop circles in the UK in 2002 were not spread randomly across the landscape. They tended to appear near roads, areas of medium-to-dense population, and cultural heritage monuments such as Stonehenge or Avebury.

Bower and Chorley 🔗

In 1991, Doug Bower and Dave Chorley, made headlines by saying they had started the crop circle phenomenon in 1978, using simple tools. To prove their case they made a circle in front of journalists; a “cereologist”, Pat Delgado, examined the circle and declared it authentic before it was revealed that it was a hoax. Inspired by Australian crop circle accounts from 1966, Bower and Chorley claimed to be responsible for all circles made prior to 1987, and for more than 200 crop circles in 1978–1991.

Art and business 🔗

After reports of simple circles in the 1970s, increasingly complex geometric designs have been created by anonymous artists, in some cases to attract tourists to an area. Since the early 1990s, the UK arts collective Circlemakers, founded by Rod Dickinson and John Lundberg, has been creating crop circles in the UK and around the world as part of its art practice and also for commercial clients. The Led Zeppelin Boxed Set that was released on 7 September 1990, features an image of a crop circle that appeared in East Field in Alton Barnes, Wiltshire. On the night of 11–12 July 1992, a crop-circle-making competition with a prize of £3,000 was held in Berkshire. In 2002, Discovery Channel commissioned five aeronautics and astronautics graduate students from MIT to create crop circles of their own. In 2009, The Guardian reported that crop circle activity had been waning around Wiltshire, in part because makers preferred creating promotional crop circles for companies that paid well for their efforts. A video sequence used in connection with the opening of the 2012 Summer Olympics in London showed two crop circles in the shape of the Olympic rings. A 3 ha (7 acres) crop circle depicting the emblem of the Star Wars Rebel Alliance was created in California in December 2017.

Legal implications 🔗

In 1992, Gábor Takács and Róbert Dallos, both then aged 17, were the first people to face legal action after creating a crop circle in Hungary. In 2000, Matthew Williams became the first man in the UK to be arrested for causing criminal damage after making a crop circle near Devizes.

Creation 🔗

Human origin 🔗

The scientific consensus on crop circles is that they are constructed by human beings as hoaxes, advertising, or art. The most widely known method for a person or group to construct a crop formation is to tie one end of a rope to an anchor point and the other end to a board which is used to crush the plants. Bower and Chorley confessed in 1991 to making the first crop circles in southern England. In a copycat effect, increasingly complex circles started appearing in many countries around the world, including fractal figures. Some crop formations are paid for by companies who use them as advertising. Hoaxers have been caught in the process of making new circles, such as in 2004 in the Netherlands.

Natural origins 🔗

Weather 🔗

It has been suggested that crop circles may be the result of extraordinary meteorological phenomena ranging from freak tornadoes to ball lightning, but there is no evidence of any crop circle being created by any of these causes. In 1880, an amateur scientist, John Rand Capron, wrote a letter to the editor of journal Nature about some circles in crops and blamed them on a recent storm. In 1980, Terence Meaden, a meteorologist and physicist, proposed that the circles were caused by whirlwinds whose course was affected by southern England hills.

Animal activity 🔗

In 2009, the attorney general for the island state of Tasmania stated that Australian wallabies had been found creating crop circles in fields of opium poppies.

Alternative explanations 🔗

In science magazines from the 1980s and 1990s, one could read reports suggesting that the plants were bent by something that could be microwave radiation, rather than broken by physical impact.

Paranormal 🔗

Since becoming the focus of widespread media attention in the 1980s, crop circles have been the subject of speculation by various paranormal, ufological, and anomalistic investigators, ranging from proposals that they were created by bizarre meteorological phenomena to messages from extraterrestrial beings. There has also been speculation that crop circles have a relation to ley lines. Some paranormal advocates think that crop circles are caused by ball lightning and that the patterns are so complex that they have to be controlled by some entity. Responding to local beliefs that “extraterrestrial beings” in UFOs were responsible for crop circles appearing, the Indonesian National Institute of Aeronautics and Space (LAPAN) described crop circles as “man-made”.

Changes to crops 🔗

A small number of scientists (physicist Eltjo Haselhoff, the late biophysicist William Levengood) have claimed to observe differences between the crops inside the circles and outside them, citing this as evidence they were not man made.

Related art 🔗

Patterns similar to crop circles can also be made in snow, by using skis, snow shoes or just walking with ordinary shoes. Patterns similar to crop circles can also be made in sand. Images can be made in forests by cutting trees, especially in areas with snow.

Folklore 🔗

Researchers of crop circles have linked modern crop circles to old folkloric tales to support the claim that they are not artificially produced. Crop circles are culture dependent: they appear mostly in developed and secularised Western countries where people are receptive to New Age beliefs, including Japan, but they do not appear at all in other zones, such as Muslim countries. Fungi can cause circular areas of crop to die, probably the origin of tales of “fairie rings”. A 17th-century English woodcut called the Mowing-Devil depicts the devil with a scythe mowing (cutting) a circular design in a field of oats. In the

source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crop_circle

item.title: Ancient astronauts
item.description:
Ancient Astronauts 🔗

Ancient astronauts, also known as ancient aliens, is a pseudoscientific belief that intelligent extraterrestrial beings visited Earth in ancient times and influenced the development of human civilization. Proponents suggest that these aliens affected modern cultures, technologies, religions, and human biology. A common idea is that deities from religions are extraterrestrial in origin, and advanced technologies were seen as divine by early humans. Academics and archaeologists dismiss these claims as pseudoarchaeological or unscientific, lacking credible peer-reviewed studies. Some argue that these theories have racist undertones, diminishing the accomplishments of indigenous cultures.

Overview 🔗

Various terms are used to describe claims about ancient astronauts, including ancient aliens, ancient ufonauts, ancient space pilots, paleocontact, astronaut- or alien gods, and paleo- or biblical-SETI. Believers often claim that humans are descendants or creations of extraterrestrial intelligence who landed on Earth in the past. They suggest that human knowledge, religion, and culture originated from these visitors, who acted as a “mother culture.” Proponents also claim that aliens built structures like the Egyptian pyramids and the Moai stone heads of Easter Island or aided humans in their construction. Evidence is said to come from gaps in historical and archaeological records and artifacts that are considered anachronistic.

As a pseudoarcheology, the idea is featured in fringe media, such as the History Channel series Ancient Aliens. The show mixes fact with fiction to spread theories of an alternate past with tropes that follow white supremacist, nativist, imperialist, settler-colonial, and Christian Identity beliefs. Proponents claim to be an oppressed minority of academics that ‘big archaeology’ is conspiring to disenfranchise.

Like archaeological endeavors of the criticized past, these proponents focus primarily on monumental archaeological structures claiming they could have only been constructed with extraterrestrial intervention. The implication is that the non-white Indigenous people in the regions in which these monuments appear could not have built them on their own. However, Dakota/Lakota Sioux writer Ruth H. Burns counters that ancient alien theory and the idea of extraterrestrials in general supports the viewpoints of indigenous, non-European peoples. She believes the denial of extraterrestrial encounters and indigenous peoples’ stories tracing their origins to extraterrestrials is part of “Indigenous erasure,” as it minimizes or completely discounts the viewpoints of indigenous peoples.

A common feature in the stories portray the aliens as light-skinned or Aryan in complexion, as prominent alien astronaut proponent Erich von Däniken claims in his foundational work Chariots of the Gods? Some ancient astronaut proponents are thus associated with white supremacism, although their theories are sometimes applied to European cultures as well.

These claims are so outlandish that up until recently, mainstream archaeologists essentially ignored them as absurdities. The few dedicated popular science explainers and skeptics who did offer opinions on the ideas universally panned them.
